SubIndicatorTextImage.heading: What are anti-bullying efforts?
SubIndicatorTextImage.subhead: Bullying usually happens because people don’t really understand each other's experiences and feelings. While we’re all unique, you’d be surprised at how much we all have in common! Anti-bullying is about everyone taking time to understand and respect each other's experiences and beliefs. This takes time so anti-bullying is also about people standing up against bullying when they see it happening. Anti-bullying is super important because when everyone is respected, we can work together toward shared goals.
SubIndicatorTextImage.bullets:
• How can you and your friends act as role models against bullying?
  • Have you ever learned ways to stop bullying in school and beyond?
  • Who are some adults that you feel comfortable with talking about bullying situations?
  • Have you and peers in school had opportunities to learn about all of the things that you have in common? What was it like?

SubIndicatorTextImage.heading: What does anti-bullying efforts include?
SubIndicatorTextImage.subhead: Your transition team can help stop bullying by making sure that you...
SubIndicatorTextImage.bullets:
• Learn why bullying happens and how to know when it’s happening
  • Practice speak up for yourself and your peers
  • Talk to friends and adults about bullying experiences
  • Share your beliefs and experiences freely while also learning all about your peers
  • Practice anti-bullying strategies for school and at work

SubIndicatorVideoImage.heading: What’s anti-bullying all about? Let’s unpack it!

IconTile2Heading.heading: What can anti-bullying do for you?
IconTile2Heading.subheading: When your team supports you with anti-bullying, you’ll have

IconTile2.heading: Self-Advocacy Skills
IconTile2.content: Learning and knowing when to speak up for yourself

IconTile2.heading: Safe Environments
IconTile2.content: Safe spaces to share your experiences and beliefs

IconTile2.heading: Sharing Opportunities
IconTile2.content: Opportunities to connect with others that have had similar experiences within your school

IconTile2.heading: Interpersonal Skills
IconTile2.content: Learning how to get along with others by finding what you have in common and respecting your differences

testimonialList.title: Transition-age youth
testimonialList.description: I got accused of talking behind a friend’s back, which I wasn’t. I was upset, I was crying. I went to the guidance office at school. They handled it, and I told my friend that I wasn’t talking about her. Then it felt a lot better. We’re still friends.

testimonialList.title: Transition-age youth
testimonialList.description: In 5th grade, this kid was calling me names that are like banana, nerd, like picking on names. I didn’t like him. Probably the boy was picking on me because I was in a special room. I told my grandma, and she told the principal, and the principal took care of it.
